I'll be there at that party for sure.
Plus.

It's incredibly easy to make.

It's really just about us and food.
MasterClass is one of the best parts of the week.
You get to actually sit back and get a little bit of knowledge from them.
Welcome to MasterClass.
Sigh of relief.
Big week.

and we questioned whether or not there was enough of fat in the rabbit to make it good.
Yeah, there were some good burgers and there were some bad burgers on the day.
But now I'm gonna show you my version of a hamburger
with a few little twists and turns.
I've got a feeling it's not something that you put between two slices of bread.
No.
It's lots of little things happening on this plate,
you're gonna get a beautiful meatloaf
with of course an egg in it, like a meatloaf should be.
You're gonna get a beetroot puree, that's just spiced with a little bit of feta.
Sun-dried tomatoes, as well as that you're gonna go some beer-battered onion rings
and batter bits.
Right guys, first step is to make the meatloaf.
So, a good quality A-grade beef mince, that's 400 grams.
A third of a cup of breadcrumbs.
You know, what I've got here is really interesting, but it's called wild rice.
It's actually not a member of the rice family, it's a grain-producing grass,
and actually grows in ponds and lakes in North America.
I've boiled these for about 30 minutes just in water, no salt at all.
And the reason why is if you put salt in the water,
it actually retards the skin and makes it really chewy.
Alright, so no salt into the water.
About a cupful.
We've got some capers. About two tablespoons.
And that's gonna add a nice saltiness to the meatloaf.
We've got some shredded parsley.
Next thing to go in is two eggs. And that's just there to bind
the mixture together.
We've also got some flavorings. We're gonna add
some whole-grain mustard.
So, a tablespoon of that.
I'm gonna also add some toasted sesame seeds, about two tablespoons worth.
And next, I've got bonito flakes.
Bonito's a fish, it's part of the tuna family, and it's sort of a cross between
tuna and mackerel.
So I add a teaspoon of bonito flakes.
That's gonna make the meat a lot more meatier in flavor.
Last step, sea salt.
And a good helping of that.
Now, what we have to do is to incorporate it all
and make sure it's the right consistency.
The consistency I'm looking for is that sort of Play-Doh consistency, you know,
you want it to form, come together, and sort of hold itself.
Not be too dry, but not bee too wet, it's that balance,
if it is too wet, you just add a bit more breadcrumb to it,
and that will soak up any moisture, but for me this is just perfect.
So my metloaf mixture is ready to go.
Next step is to make the meatloaf.
Right, guys, what I've got here is just some jamon, some
beautiful spanish jamon, flavorsome, you know, you can use pancetta,
or prosciutto, really thinly sliced. Why I chose jamon, cause a little bit more mild,
not so salty as the prosciutto.
What we wanna basically do is form a nice slab of mixture,
three quarters way up the ham.
Right, I've got boiled eggs.
Now what I'm doing is basically top and tailing the whole eggs.
Cause what I wanna do, I need to join this.
So basically when I slice into this, I wanna see the egg in the middle.
Okay. Now, the fun bit. Rolling it up. Wish me luck.
it's really important that you get it nice and tight. Really, really important.
Cause you want this to be perfect and round.
Alright. At that point I'm happy. Really, really happy.
I've got some heavy-duty, sort of kitchen-grade plastic wrap.
Alright, it's a little bit thicker. It can take, you know, high heats.
And of course, it's a little bit wider as well.
- Yes, Joanne? - If you can't get that plastic wrap,
can you use just a normal... - You can, but you'll need a load of it.
Yeah, make a few layers? Okay.
Alright. Next step is to cryovac this meatloaf,
so we'll be using the cryovac machine.
To remove all the air and seal this bag.
If you don't have a cryovac machine, take your wrapped-up meatloaf,
and pop that into a ziplock bag.
Beautiful. Done.
Now, next step, we need to cook it. Waterbath, 68 degrees,
that goes in, timer on for 40 minutes.
And that will be cooked beautifully.
If you don't have a water bath at home, maybe get a fish poacher,
or a big pot. Fill it up with water, pop an old-school thermometer in it,
nothing wrong with that.
Next step, what's a burger without beetroot, come on, all us Aussies sitting here.
I love beetroot. But what we're gonna do is make a beatroot and feta dip, so to speak.
We've basically taken whole beetroots, wrap them up in foil,
a little bit of sea salt, little bit of olive oil, and baked them in an oven
at about 160 degrees for about a hour and a half.
We've taken them out of the oven, we've let them cool down,
we've peeled the skin, and just blended it up.
Some feta. And this is gonna add some nice saltiness and creaminess to it.
Squeeze in the old fella, some olive oil.
That's our beetroot and feta dip made, so that's our beetroot component.
What's a hamburger without a sesame seed bun?
Well. I've taken the humble sesame seed bun, and I've toasted it.
And then I've popped these into the freezer.
I've then blended them while they're frozen into a powder.
Alright?
So that forms my hamburger bun soil.
We call this a soil, cause it resembles the texture of soil.
Nice little flavor, it's gonna add a real complexity into this dish.
After the break.
So we've got that beautiful egg in the center.
George serves his five-star gourmet burger.
Last but not least, the onion rings go on the plate.
Then later.
That's the beauty of Japanese food.
As complex as it tastes, it's incredibly easy to make.
The basics for cooking Japanese with star chef Shaun Presland.
Plus.
Gee, they look great, don't they?
You've gotta have a tomato sauce, eh?
Gary has easy to prepare food for a kids' party.
That looks pretty adult and absolutely gorgeous.

at 68 degrees. We've removed it from the water bath
and placed that in the fridge to cool down.
We removed the meatloaf from the cryovac bag,
and this is where we pray again, hoping it's gonna look beautiful inside.
So we've got that beautiful egg in the center,
not overcooked in any way, shape or form,
beautiful nice and pink meat. It's not brown looking
even though it's cooked through.
Really important, there's nothing worse than going to a restaurant
and you're gonna cut into your entree, and you find clean film.
There is nothing worse.
And trust me, it's happened in my restaurant
and I nearly killed someone. Alright?
People don't pay for that stuff.
Onto a plate.
Just to dress it, and we wanna gloss it up, give it some sexiness.
Little bit of olive oil, and we just glaze that up.
That looks beautiful.
Right, time to plate up our inspiration of a hamburger,
but before we do that, we need to make some onion rings, and
Gaz, I heard you're the expert in onion rings.
- You want them set out? - This is actually your recipe,
that you gave to me and I love it. 150 grams of corn flour,
150 grams of self-raising flour, 300 mils of beer,
and a half teaspoon of bicarb soda. And you just mix it all together.
Alright. So we put the dry ingredients together.
So that's the corn flour going into the flour, and then the bicarb.
A pinch of salt, which is important.
And that's self-raising flour, not plain flour.
If you're using plain flour, you just add a teaspoon of baking powder.
You add a little bit of the beer into the middle
and you just create that batter in a well,
and then you just slowly add all the liquid,
and draw the dry ingredients into that paste.
And really you're just making that batter to consistency of thick cream.
And you can use that for fish, prawns, scallops, vegetables.
Pickles. Fried pickles.
We've got to put those little onion rings, and beautiful little onion rings they are.
Gotta toss them in flour. The reason you toss them in flour is if you didn't
when you put them in the batter, all the batter would slip off,
as soon as you put them in the frier.
So we're just gonna toss them in the batter itself,
and then just drop them in
one at a time,
and allow them to separate off into the oil.
And we just want a light coating.
That oil is about 170 degrees.
A good frying temperature for most things if you want a crisp batter,
is around 170 to 185. Depending on how big the item is,
how quickly it's gonna cook.
So these little onion rings are looking good.
Nice golden brown, nice and crisp.
- The few little battery bits, George. - Yum.
I'm gonna start plating this burger up.

Little drizzle of olive oil. The same with cornichons. They are my ultimate favorite.

A little bit more olive oil for glossiness.
Our beetroot we're just gonna pop into...
a piping bag.
Snip the end,
and we start to plate up here.
Next step is to put our meatloaf on the plate.

And then of course our sesame seed bun soil.
This is the bread element to the dish.
Right.
And of course, a few little cresses.
Last but not least, the onion rings go on the plate.
And then all of these little battered bits, which are texturally...
unbelievable.
They're just beautiful. They go in there as well.
Right. So this is my inspiration from the hamburger challenge,
basically in essence we've made a meatloaf.
A meatloaf with a few little interesting flavors and spices,

Claire, Dominic and Sharnee. Come up and taste.
Cheers.

Dominic.

I love it. I think the texture is definitely the standout thing.

Hard to pick up in your hands and eat.
A little bit.

There's lots of versatile techniques in this dish,
that you guys can use.

Can I order one of them?
Okay, guys, go and sit back down.
My top tips to make a burger. That meatloaf, cook it at low temperature.
In turn that will help that egg inside not to overcook and go brown.
Number two, make sure you wrap the meatloaf with lots of clean film,
and that will assist when you cook it. You'll get even temperature,
and you won't overcook that egg.
Top tip number three, beetroot and feta dip.
Simple. Beetroots, roasted, make sure they cook through.
If it's a puree, it's gotta be nice and silky smooth.
This dish isn't about being too clever, it's about taking something so humble

Taking all those elements with a little bit of skill and some refinement,
producing a dish worthy to sit in a good restaurant
or be served in a great function.
- Drained. - Next on MasterClass.
This is the medium tofu. It's the best one to fry.
A Japanese classic that's incredibly easy to prepare.

I'm gonna be one of the four to be involved in the MasterClass with Shaun Presland.
Walking into Sake restaurant, first thing I notice

Guys, I'd now like to introduce you to the executive chef at Sake restaurant,
Shaun Presland.

Pleased to meet you.
Japanese food's all about being fresh.
My cooking style is trying to keep things simple.
Let the food speak for itself.

Even though Shaun is not Japanese, he's had 17 years

Alright. Today we're talking about tofu. Basically there's three main types of tofu.
The silken tofu. A momen tofu, which is, means cotton, semi-soft.
And a hard tofu. All made from soy beans that have been boiled.
You can see, very jelly, not so jelly, very hard.
So Shaun, what are we gonna do with this fantastic tofu?
We're gonna do Agedashi Tofu.
We're gonna crumb it in potato starch, give it a lovely coating,
and then deep fry it at 170 degrees.
So the essence of good Agedashi would be what, that contrast between two textures?
The crunchy outside, beautiful creamy soft inside, a lovely dipping sauce,
some aromatics, so we're using some ginger and some scallions.
We've got some grated radish. Radish is good, because in the sauce it will
bind the sauce together.
Another reason we have radish is it aids in digesting oils,
so we're gonna put something in the fryer, we want some radish to clean our system out
so that oil doesn't stay in our bodies.
There's always a story behind everything in Japanese food.
Very healthy way to eat.
So let's go.
Yeah, alright.
This potato starch, I like a chunky one. it's kind of unrefined.
This tofu's been drained.
Just confirming, is that the medium tofu that you showed us before?
This is the medium tofu. It's the best one to fry.
And the soft one's gonna fall apart. The hard one's not gonna
take as much flavor and it's not gonna be creamy in the center, so definitely.
Could you use anything else to coat the tofu?
If you didn't have potato starch for example?
You can use corn flour, you can use flour,
to get the crunchiest outside, potato starch is the best.
So you're always using a dry flour or starch with agadashi,
there's never a batter, there's no egg coating?
- No. - Just simple as that.
Very simple. Very simple. I'm putting it in a fryer at 170.
Tempura normally fry at 180, but agadashi tofu at 170.
- Why is that? - I want it to cook a little bit slowly,
only to get a lovely brown golden fox color coating on the outside.
If you're cooking too hot, too quickly, it's just gonna burn.
That takes about four minutes to cook.
So, the tofu is frying, let's make the sauce.
Dipping sauce for agadashi tofu. Teaspoon of hondashi,
which is a dashi powder, into the bowl. A cup, 180 mil, of boiling water.
Give it a little stir.
And voila, instant dashi. Six parts dashi,
and say one part light soy, and one part mirin.
Give it a stir, it's nice and hot, and to that we're gonna add some grated radish.
Again, for digestion, and because you see, it gives like, they call it mizureni.
It almost looks like falling snow as it comes through the sauce.
So many japanese dishes are as simple as that.
That's the beauty of Japanese food. As complex as it tastes,
it's incredibly easy to make, and I love people try to overcomplicate
making Japanese dishes.
Not understanding it really is not that difficult.
Tofu's been in for about four to five minutes,
and if you look at the color, potato starch is lovely and crunchy.
I'm gonna plate that up, just three pieces on the plate.
Lovely aromatics, we've got some ginger,
we've got some scallions.
Soy sauce.
Sort of over.
That's us done. Agadashi tofu.

Have a taste. On your experience, the crunchiness,

Dig in.
Get stuck in, guys.

Freshness of ingredients, temperature of your oil,
agadashi tofu 170. And serve it immediately,
so it's nice and crunchy.

Kids' party food that's good for them.

Now let's look at the kids' birthday party challenge.
I'm sure you guys are still recovering.
It was a scorching hot day and your first out cater

Hi!
150 guests, half of them kids, and of course their parents.
And what we asked you to do is devise a menu

you had a disaster really, didn't you? You made sausage rolls.

The meat was cooked through, but they looked pretty average.
So, sausage roll is gonna be my first little show and tell.
Now, you know, we thought about the kids' food ourselves.
I've got a little daughter, she's nine,
and I've looked after every single birthday party that she's had.
Cakes included. And this is a lesson that I've learned cooking for my daughter,
is that all kids, unless they're exceptional kids,
they'll pick out and find every little vegetable that you put in something.
I remember my daughter picking out the tiniest bit of zucchini and going,
Ew, you put zucchini in there, I'm not eating it,
and it's just been dinner time turning into a disaster.
And I learned this little technique.
So I'm gonna show it to you, and we're gonna incorporate that
into our little party sausage roll.
George, go take a break, have a cup of tea.
I might bring back some tomato sauce for the sausage rolls.
Good idea.
Ok, the little veggie trick.
Grate vegetables and make a puree. And then fold the puree
into the sausage roll mix. It really works.
What I do is grate the carrot or pumpkin, for example,
a little bit of butter or oil.
Doesn't even need oil if you don't want to. It can be a little bit of water.
And then just put the grated vegetable into the pot, build a little bit of heat up,
stirring regularly, and then pop a lid on.
Now if you're doing a cauliflower puree, you can do it the exactly same way,
or you can cook it with a little bit of milk.
But shred finely. Whatever vegetable it is, shred it finely.
And that'll take about 4-5 minutes to really soften,
and then the secret there is to use a blender, puree it,
and puree it until it's really, really fine, so you don't have to parse it
or do anything more to it. And at the end of it,
you'll end up with a nice bright puree.
Okay, so the next thing we're gonna do is fry a little bit of onion.

it'll just blend into the mince. And I want to cook it,
you don't have to cook it, but I notice when you cook it that
it will be just nice and soft in that sausage roll.
And remember, you should cook this only for a couple of minutes,
and then cool it down before mixing it with the mince
and the puree.
And the reason you cool it down is just before you've gotta be careful at every stage
not to warm the mixture up. Because it's a risk you know, every stage,
especially out catering, like you guys were,
of poisoning a lot of people if you're not careful.
So, onions into the oil, a little bit of garlic.
And then these little flavor dimensions,
even though we're cooking something for the kids,
if I cook kids' food, I eat it too, so I want a bit of flavor in there,

And you do need a little bit of fat in there, but that's actually,
that is actually quite lean.
And now what I'm using is the puree and you can put as much

Don't need to put eggs in now.
Gonna put a bit of oregano, and salt, and I actually avoid putting pepper in,

And then add the cold, cooked onions to the meat mix.
I added breadcrumbs, about two cups of breadcrumbs in there.

you'll get a little bit of fat leech out of it, you might have a bit of water,

Don't forget you can use chicken mince, nice and easy,

I'd use something like ricotta which is a good base

Should we divide it in half?

And then what we're gonna do is pop those on the tray, go on, off you go.
Eggwash them, and pop them in the oven.

Alright, pop it on.

I've got sesame seeds and I've got basil seeds as well.

Makes it look nice.

Okay. Sausage rolls. 101 MasterClass.
So top tips. First point. Try not to use commercially made sausage mince.
They've got fillers and binders in them. Use fresh mince. Chicken, lamb, beef.
